metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Assessee (Respondent)

facts.text: Respondent is a businessman engaged in multiple activities including railway contracting, running rice mill and sugar factory, and supplying limestone and dolomite from quarry at Paraghat.
Agreement dated January 5, 1935 between respondent and Bengal Iron Company Ltd. for exclusive purchase of all requirements of limestone and dolomite at specified rates.
Agreement modified by another agreement dated December 21, 1935.
In 1936, Bengal Iron Company went into liquidation; assets and liabilities taken over by Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. under scheme dated September 8, 1936.
Indian Iron and Steel Company continued purchasing but later terminated due to uneconomic rates, notice dated May 29, 1939.
Respondent filed Suit No. 211 of 1940 in Calcutta High Court for specific performance and injunction; injunction issued on March 13, 1940.

Settlement agreement dated May 9, 1940: Respondent to work Company's quarry at Gangapur for 25 years, supply limestone; paid Rs. 4,000 monthly for 18 months, then Rs. 2-9-0 per ton; respondent to provide machinery, workmen, etc.; clause 6 for additional supplies; clause 13 restricting other quarry contracts within 20 miles except own quarries.
Railway authorities did not permit siding at Gangapur, making agreement impossible to perform as contemplated.

New agreement dated August 2, 1941 terminating May 9, 1940 contract: Company pays Rs. 2,50,000 as solatium plus balance monthly instalments; new 12-year contracts for limestone supply to Kulti furnaces and loading iron ore at Monoharpore.
Rs. 2,50,000 paid to respondent pursuant to August 2, 1941 agreement; balance monthly payments also paid; new agreements executed.
Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 2,50,000 as trading receipt liable to tax.
Appellate Tribunal affirmed ITO and AAC, held trading receipt.

On respondent's application, Tribunal referred question under s.66(1) of 1922 Act to High Court: Whether Rs. 2,50,000 as damages/compensation for premature termination of May 9, 1940 contract is income assessable.
Nagpur High Court (Sen and Deo JJ.) in Misc. Civil Case No. 135 of 1949 held capital receipt not liable to tax; dismissed certificate under s.66A(2).
Supreme Court granted special leave under Art. 136.
Respondent claimed before ITO that amount was for termination of 1935 contract, not substantiated; no evidence of capital expenses over Rs.4 lakhs on Paraghat quarry.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 received by the respondent on August 2, 1941 as solatium for termination of the contract dated May 9, 1940 is a revenue receipt chargeable to income-tax or a capital receipt not liable to tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: The contract dated May 9, 1940 was entered into in ordinary course of business; Rs. 2,50,000 is solatium for cancellation representing profits that would have been made; hence trading/revenue receipt.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Short Bros. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue; Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Northfleet Coal and Ballast Co. Ltd.; Jesse Robinson Sons v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue

petitioner_arguments.text: Agreements were adjustments in ordinary course of business, similar to prior modifications.

respondent_arguments.text: Rs. 2,50,000 reimburses capital expenses exceeding Rs. 4 lakhs incurred for 1935 contract (quarters, etc.) thrown away on abandonment of Paraghat quarry.
Contract of May 9, 1940 for 25 years (23 years unexpired) is enduring capital asset; compensation for termination is capital receipt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Shaw Wallace Co.; Barr, Crombie Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue; Van Den Berghs Ltd. v. Clark

respondent_arguments.text: Contract created framework to carry on business, not the business itself; specialised business formed entirety of activities; termination sterilises capital asset.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Van Den Berghs Ltd. v. Clark; Glenboig Union Fireclay Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue

court_reasoning.text: No evidence substantiating capital expenses claim for Paraghat quarry; amount linked to 1940 contract termination, not 1935.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rs. 2,50,000 not reimbursement of thrown-away capital expenditure.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent's limestone supply is ordinary business activity; May 9, 1940 contract part of that business; termination solatium is trading receipt like in Short Bros., Northfleet Coal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contract entered in ordinary course of business; supplier/dealer distinction immaterial.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes agency contracts (capital if structure of business) from trading contracts (revenue); long duration does not change trading contract to capital asset.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compensation for trading contract termination is revenue, unlike agency cessation.

court_reasoning.text: Not framework apart from business (contra Van Den Berghs); business is raising/supplying limestone under contract.
Not sterilisation by external authority (contra Glenboig); settlement of trading rights, no bar to other business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment adjusts profits under trading contract.

holdings.text: Sum of Rs. 2,50,000 is revenue receipt chargeable to income-tax under Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

precedents_cited.case_name: Van Den Berghs Ltd. v. Clark
precedents_cited.relevance: Agreements were structure of profit-making apparatus, not trading contracts; inapplicable to ordinary course trading contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: Davies v. H.M. Inspector of Taxes The Shell Company of China Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Questions of capital vs income involve conclusion of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rustproof Metal Window Co., Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Capital vs income questions of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Short Bros. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Cancellation payment for shipbuilding contract in ordinary business is revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Northfleet Coal and Ballast Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Compensation for terminating supply contract is revenue, representing commuted profits.
Sale of contracts by stranger is capital; not applicable to settlement between parties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jesse Robinson Sons v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for buyer breach on sale contract is trading receipt.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Shaw Wallace Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Agency termination for business cessation is capital.

precedents_cited.case_name: Barr, Crombie Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Managing agency as sole asset; extinction payment capital.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kelsall Parsons Co. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Agency termination (one year left) in course of agency business is revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. South India Pictures Ltd., Karaikudi
precedents_cited.relevance: Film distribution contracts termination compensation is revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Golden Horse Shoe (New) Ltd. v. Thurgood
precedents_cited.relevance: Nature depends on trade: fixed vs circulating capital.

precedents_cited.case_name: Glenboig Union Fireclay Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory sterilisation of capital asset (field) is capital; inapplicable to trading contract settlement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shove v. Dura Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Commission agreement termination payment is revenue.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court and certificate for appeal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Nagpur High Court set aside; order of Appellate Tribunal restored holding Rs. 2,50,000 as taxable revenue receipt.
outcome.relief_granted: Department's view upheld; amount chargeable to income-tax.

key_quotes.text: "the question whether a receipt is capital or income... must ultimately depend on the facts of the particular case"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes case-specific nature of capital vs revenue distinction.

key_quotes.text: "Such a contract is part of the business itself... and any receipt on account of such a contract can only be a trading receipt."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing trading contracts from agency agreements.

key_quotes.text: "when once it is found that a contract was entered into in the ordinary course of business, any compensation received for its termination would be a revenue receipt"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule applied to facts, irrespective of duration.
